Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Interference Management for Visible Light Communications via Poisson Model

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Visible light communication (VLC) is emerging as a viable alternative wireless transmission technology that could potentially alleviate the spectrum scarcity problem. VLC uses ordinary light sources such as light emitting diodes (LEDs) as the communication medium, and superposes a high frequency on/off operation on top of light sources for data transmissions. Compared to radio communications, the advantages of VLC include several orders broader in bandwidth, very little regulatory restrictions, ubiquitous light sources, and higher level of security for transmissions. One of the main challenges in the design of VLC at the physical layer is the issue of interference caused by simultaneous transmissions of multiple sources due to diffusion of lights emitted from regular light sources. While interference management for the Gaussian model (valid for the strong background light noise regime) is relatively well understood, it is mostly unexplored for the Poisson model (valid for the low background light noise regime).

This project will design novel interference management techniques for VLC in the Poisson regime, analyze the corresponding transmission rates/throughputs for VLC, and develop information theoretic methodologies to characterize the fundamental communication limits on these transmission rates. The proposed research is expected to make substantial contributions to both applications and theory. On the application side, this project is anticipated to substantially advance our understanding of interference management for VLC, and provide important guidelines for designing high throughput and resource efficient VLC networks. On the theoretical level, the project will develop new stochastic calculus and information theoretic tools to advance our understanding of Poisson channels. The PIs will also use this project as a great platform to attract and train students from diverse backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Recent proliferation of wireless applications boosts increasingly high data rate demands on radio communication systems, whose capacities are, however, substantially limited by the scarcity of the radio spectrum. Visible light communications (VLC) has emerged as a promising new wireless technology. VLC uses ordinary light sources and superposes a high frequency on/off operation on visible light for transmitting data information. Using visible light as the communication medium, VLC taps into a vast amount of untouched spectrum. There are two models for VLC: the Gaussian and Poisson models, valid respectively for scenarios with strong and low background noise. While the Gaussian models have been extensively studied in the literature, Poisson models have not been explored much yet. Thus, this project focuses on developing information theoretic methodologies to characterize the fundamental communication limits for VLC in the Poisson regime, and designing novel communication schemes, particularly interference management techniques, for Poisson models to achieve the optimal transmission rates.

This project has performed a comprehensive investigation of a number of important Poisson models, characterized the capacity for these models in various cases, and designed achievable transmission strategies to achieve the capacity. In particular, this project successfully accomplished the following major research findings.

1. We investigated Poisson fading channels with varying noise levels, which is motivated by applications of visible light communication systems with the noise level affected by the strength of the background light. We characterized both the ergodic and outage capacities, respectively corresponding to communication scenarios without and with delay constraints, for both the single-input single-output (SISO) and the multiple-input and multiple-output (MIMO) channels.  We also found the optimal power allocation over time (as well as across transmit antennas for MIMO channels) to achieve the capacities.

2. We investigated the (nonsymmetric) SISO Poisson multiple-access channel (MAC), and characterized the sum capacity via solving a nonconvex optimization problem by characterizing the KKT conditions that the optimal solution must satisfy. We further generalized our study to the multi-input single-output (MISO) Poisson MAC, and characterized the sum capacity by two novel steps that exploit the properties of the optimal transmission schemes.

3. We investigated the two-user Poisson interference channel, which serves as a basic model for visible light communications (VLC). We identified the conditions for the strong interference regime and characterized the corresponding capacity region. For the cases when the strong interference conditions are not satisfied, we provided inner and outer bounds on the capacity region. We also studied the Poisson Z-interference channel, and obtained the sum rate capacity when the cross link coefficient is either sufficiently small or sufficiently large.

Broader Impact: 

This project developed novel communication schemes and interference management techniques for Poisson models, which will be useful guidelines for substantially improving communication efficiency of VLC. In particular, the time-adaptive and antenna-adaptive power allocation schemes that we derived will potentially improve power efficiency of VLC significantly. The project also advanced the state-of-the-art of the understanding of performance limits for multiuser Poisson channels. The analysis techniques developed here can be generalized to solve other problems for multiuser Poisson channels as well.

This project has partially supported four students to develop their PhD research including one female student Ruchen Duan. Two students Ruchen Duan and Shaofeng Zou have successfully defended their PhD Thesis. This project provided these students with great opportunities to learn and practise techniques in network information theory, probability theory and random processes and trained them to solve engineering problems via information theoretic tools. The findings in this project have been brought to several classes including Network Information Theory, Stochastic Processes, and Probabilistic Methods.

The findings of this project have yielded three journal papers on IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, one journal paper on IEEE Transactions on Communications, and one paper under review by IEEE Transactions on Information Theory. This project has also lead to eleven publications on high-quality conferences. These publications have disseminated the results to a wider range of researchers in various communities. The PI Liang also attended the Nexus Workshop of Information and Computation Theories in March 2016, held in Paris, France, during which the PI Liang discussed the findings of this project with researchers in Information Theory and received useful feedback.
